title: Who will win the 2020 Taiwan presidential election?
preds: Tsai is leading in the polls with a big margin. It is unlikely that China's interference will change the result but if it does it will be Han.

Global Instability, trade war benefits Taiwan, good economic condition, HK protest, Han is too pro-China, Tsai unorthodox diplomatic actions, negative news on China like xin jiang camp, tsai gain lots of support from young supporters. Latest opinion poll sides with President tsai
Rounded to 100. Absence of any upsetting news and twenty points win difference makes the odd less than 5 in 1,000 to me.
Even more convinced after looking at polls.
All the polls indicates a Tsai Ing-Wen win

Late to see this question ... Interesting read: https://www.lowyinstitute.org/publications/taiwan-s-2020-elections Heartening that China's heavy handed election interference appears to be backfiring but alarming how extensive the efforts are.
Tsai Ing-wen has a 30 point lead in the polls. There aren't many instances of poll leads like this being lost with under a week to go until the election.

Who will win the 2020 Taiwan presidential election?
Hattip @Raisinville for the pointer and I'll join the consensus of others with data as well.

Polls on News Lense have 17% lead for Tsai and she is trending upwards for half a year. Tsai wins unless the polling system is broken or there are major news in the last week.  I guess the news scandal would already have happened if eg Han had some dirt on Tsai. I couldn't find much on reliability of Taiwanese polls so adding 1% for Han for that.
Given election polling history , only few contested elections. With thirty percent difference it is uncontested and no precedent for such an upheaval days before election

Having had a quick look at the opinion polls, well... Tsai is ahead by a few standard deviations, from which I would be tempted to put a 100% on the answer. But well, it's politics, something unexpected could happen.

Base rate - based on latest press releases regarding election polls (Nikkei Asian Review, Kyodo News, Guardian) until further updates Opinion polls Dec 31
- 53% Tsai
- 22% Han
- 10% Soong Assumed:
- James Soong may surge and take votes from Tsai
- Tsai has the youth vote and anti-Beijing vote
- As long as HK simmers, anti-Beijing news will continue to trickle in the media (pushing Tsai's base)
This election is a referendum on the Beijing response to HK protests, with pro-HK sympathy buoying the DPP candidate.

Tsai is leading by substantial margins in opinion polling as of now, and those margins are unlikely to decrease. The DPP's anti-Beijing platform will remain popular especially as the conflict in Hong Kong remains unresolved and is likely to increase in popularity if the CCP cracks down in Hong Kong. This is the core differentiating issue between the DPP and the KMT, so it's not possible to circumvent or that it'll become less important. Even a substantial economic downturn or other change in conditions would likely be attributed to Beijing's attempts to attack Taiwan. Attempts by Beijing or Beijing-affiliated media to promote anti-DPP disinformation can similarly be leveraged as an attack on Taiwan.

Since the enactment of the 1947 constitution, Taiwanese presidents - except for Lee Teng-hui who voluntarily stepped down after a term - have all served two terms. Also, DPP's stance against unification with China sets it apart from the opposition. The latter point has helped DPP garner popular support, particularly from younger voters. Although Taiwan's economy has not been great and Tsai Ing-Wen has lost a lot of the support that brought her to power; she remains politically savvy. This is evidenced by her move to make the more popular premiere William lai her running mate.

Cheng, C. (2019). Latest poll shows DPP ahead of KMT by 10%. Taiwan News. Nov. 25, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3824398 In the most recent poll results revealed by the Taiwanese Public Opinion Foundation (TPOF) on Monday (Nov. 25), Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen (蔡英文) leads the Kuomintang's (KMT) Han Kuo-yu (韓國瑜) by 29 percentage points in the 2020 election. Zheng, S. (2019). Could Hong Kong protests give Tsai Ing-wen the edge in Taiwan’s presidential race? South China Morning News. Politics. Nov. 24, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3039052/could-hong-kong-protests-give-tsai-ing-wen-edge-taiwans

The upcoming presidential election in Taiwan is “all about China”. Background: The two major political parties in Taiwan are the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Kuomintang (KMT).  A smaller party that fields a presidential candidate for the 2020 election is the People First Party (PFP). KMT is the political party that ruled China before the Communists won and took over China.  After retreated to Taiwan in 1949, KMT has ruled Taiwan for many years. In the old days, KMT declared the Taiwan is part of the Republic of China (ROC) and it is the legitimate ruler of China. It follows the slogan “there is only one China” and someday China will unite under the banner of KMT.  Strangely enough, currently KMT is friendlier towards “Communist China” (the People’s Republic of China).     DPP was formed after the liberalization of politics in Taiwan in 1980’s. While not advocating publicly for the independence of Taiwan, its policies are more independently minded and less friendly towards China.  The current Taiwan president is Tsai from DPP. She won in the last election (2016), defeating the KMT candidate by a large margin (56 versus 30) [1].  However, DPP encountered a huge setback in the 2018 local elections [2], mostly due to economic issues.  Its loss includes the election of Han Kuo-yu (KMT) as the mayor of Kaohsiung, a stronghold for DPP.  Han since has become the KMT presidential candidate for the 2020 election. 2020 election: Initially it appears that DPP would lose in the upcoming 2020 presidential election.  Early polls (up to about the end of April 2019) show Han leading Tsai by about 50 to 35 [3].  However, the poll numbers started to change in July 2019.  Over the months, Tsai’s poll numbers gradually turned around to lead Han by 45 to 30 [3].   Indeed, the latest poll in November has Tsai leading by 55 to 25 [4]. The turning around for Tsai (DPP) coincides with the increasingly violent pro-democratic protests in Hong Kong.  The violent police crackdown and the rigid responses from the governments in Hong Kong and China expose the delusion of the “one country, two system” motto.  The events in Hong Kong reveal to the Taiwanese that living under the imposition of Taiwan being part of China and “one country, two system” motto could just mean living under the dictatorship of Communist China.  The fear of Communist China helps to elevate DPP’s (and Tsai’s) poll numbers.   Recent events also help the DPP.  The report of Chinese spy trying to infiltrate the Australian Parliament [5], and the arrest of 2 local company executives for spying for China [6] highlighted the attempt of China in influencing the politics in Taiwan.  The landslide victory by pro-democracy forces in the Hong Kong local election [7] highlights the hope for opposing totalitarianism.   

China is not going to change its totalitarian ways.  So my forecast is Tsai’s poll numbers will continue to rise and she will win the election in January 2020.

Reduced the probability for a win by Han after comparing the current opinion polls with those polls four years ago. Current polls show a comfortable lead of Tsai (55,2%) over Han (26,3%) [1]. This is comparable to the polls in 2015, in which Tsai led Han by ~45% to ~20% at this point of time in the election campaign [2]. [1] https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3824398

Tweaking my guess to make a bit more distance between me and the crowd in the direction of the likely outcome.
Basing my initial estimate off the daily poll tracking, which shows TIW in a clear lead and HKY in a strong second place, fairly steadily.

The current political landscape seems to be strongly in favor of Tsai Ing-wen.  This includes the candidacy of James Soong (dividing the mainland-friendly vote [10]), the conflict in Hong Kong and the investigation into alleged Chinese election meddling (donations to Han Kuo-you [1], self-confessed spy claiming election intervention in favor of Han Kuo-you in the last mayoral polls for Kaohsiung [1, 2, 6], detention of two executives of a Hong Kong firm under suspicion of being Chinese spies [3]). In particular, the situation in Hong Kong may have a mobilizing effect for young voters [7]. However, there is still time and there is still more to learn about the main contenders and the political dynamics in Taiwan politics, e.g. their respective voter bases, mobilization and policy issues [4, 5, 6]. As [4] claims and [8] and [9] underscore, Tsai's firm attitude towards China could worry some voters and may be beneficial to Han after all. It also remains to be seen if Terry Gou exerts influence in favor of Han's bid or if he abstains from the election completely after he withdrew his own candidacy [5].

Revising up the probability of President Ing-wen winning re-election, given recent news that "Authorities in Taiwan have begun an investigation into claims that...Han Kuo-yu, the presidential candidate for the mainland-friendly Kuomintang (KMT) party, accepted a 20 million yuan (US$2.8 million) donation from Beijing in the run-up to his victory in the Kaohsiung mayoral election in November last year." [1] See my earlier post for further analysis [2]. [1] https://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3039076/taiwan-investigates-spys-claim-beijing-spent-us200-million
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/926482

I first look at the direct Presidential elections in Taiwan. This started in 1996, so very limited data.  4 presidents have been elected this way: Lee TH (1996 May - 2000 May), Chen SB (2000 May - 2008 May), Ma YJ (2008 May - 2016 May) and the current incumbent Tsai IW (2016 May - Present).  Only in 1 instance has the reigning incumbent failed to get elected to a second term (Lee TH).  Hence Probability (Incumbent failed to be elected to second term) = 1/3.   Then I look at the number of years each president is in office.  Despite not being directly elected to a second term, Lee became president in 1988-Jan, giving him 12.3 years in office.  Both Chen and Ma had 8 years in office.  So Probability (Incumbent have 4 years or less in office) = 0. A simple average of the above gives Probability (Incumbent failed to get re-elected) = 0.17.  I round this up to 0.2 to account for very limited data set.  Not too scientific, but enough time spent.  Hence Prob (Tsai wins) = 0.8. To allocate the remaining 0.2, I look at the political parties of past presidents. Lee and Ma are from KMT.  Chen and Tsai from DPP.  Hence, all remaining 0.2 goes to Han Kuo-yu.

President Tsai Ing-wen is running for re-election and the odds for her re-election seem to favor her. She won in a landslide in 2016 [1], garnering ~56% of the vote in a three-way race (the other candidates received 31% and 13%).  She is again in a three-way race [2] and recent polling (there are four polls from the past ten days that reflect this three-way race) has her winning, on average, ~42% of the vote. This is compared to an average of ~25% for Han Kuo-yu and ~8% for James Soong [3]. Also, news has literally just broke that a Chinese spy has defected to Australia and has released a trove of information on China's foreign influence operations - a key target of which has been Taiwan and its upcoming presidential election [4]. This is huge news (as such a defection seems to have never happened before) and it is sure to work in President Ing-wen's favor, as she is seen as more hawkish on China than her opponents. This will likely hurt Kuo-yu, who is second in the polls, since the defector seems to have indicated that China's influence operation has been working to advance his candidacy. And, of course, the ongoing Hong Kong protests probably also help President Ing-wen - but I assume that this is already reflected in the polling since the polling is recent. [2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Taiwan_presidential_election
